Award.AwardTitle: Noyce and S-STEM Mini-conference for Nevada and Southern Utah

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dixie State University will organize a proposal-writing workshop at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas. The main activities of the workshop will be conducted by NSF staff and include participation of past NSF grant recipients in the area. The PI estimates that there will be 45 participants at the workshop from southern Utah and Nevada. She expects attendance from faculty members at Southern Utah University (SUU), Dixie State University (DSU), the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, the College of Southern Nevada (CSN), the University of Nevada at Reno, and Nevada State College (NSC). Twenty-nine of the anticipated forty-five participants have already expressed an interest in attending. The grant will cover travel costs for participants from SUU, DSU, and Reno as well as meals and refreshments for working lunches and discussion breaks during the workshop.

The workshop is designed to raise awareness of funding opportunities for NSF program in the Division of Undergraduate Education in a geographical area that does not have any Noyce grants. The program includes a panel discussion with current NSF grant recipients, an outline of funding opportunities, a workshop on effective grant writing, a mock review panel, a brainstorming session to get started on grant writing ideas, and a question and answer session. Participant selection will focus on a diversity of representation from different schools and STEM disciplines. Because of the need for qualified secondary STEM teachers in high-needs schools in this geographical region, the potential for generating high-impact Noyce proposals is high. The student population in the targeted schools make them good potential sites for S-STEM proposals as well.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for Noyce and S-STEM Mini-Conference for Nevada and Southern Utah

The goal of this project was to hold a day-long informational workshop for university and college personnel to learn more about the Noyce and S-STEM programs and to network with potential regional campus. There were 39 registrants from six institutions (University of Nevada, Las Vegas, University of Nevada, Rena, the College of Southern Nevada, the Desert Research Institute, Dixie State University, and Southern Utah University). We were able to accept all applicants who applied to attend and all were in a STEM or related field. Activities included presentations by two NSF staff members, informal networking time, and a brainstorming session for future proposals. While more formal activities had been planned, the NSF staff members elected to allow participants to brainstorm when it appeared that productive conversations were developing during the event after polling participants for their preferences.

At the end of the spring semester 2019, a survey was sent to participants to determine the impact of the workshop. Sixteen responses were received from participants representing four of the six institutions. Participants were asked to rate the usefulness of the event, the presentations by the NSF, and the brainstorming session that followed the presentations. On a scale of 1-5 with five being helpful and 1 being not helpful, the usefulness of the workshop had an average response of 4.4, the NSF staff presentations had an average of 4.5, and the brainstorming session had an average of 4.1. The workshop increased the likelihood of participants submitting a proposal for 81.25% of those who attended and 93.75% were considering submitting a proposal in 2020. By April 2019, five participants had submitted an S-STEM proposal and two participants had started developing a Noyce proposal. Although a goal of the workshop was to increase multi-institutional proposals, none of the responding participants reported that any proposal in development in 2019 included more than their own institution.

Several other grant programs were covered by the NSF staff present including HIS-specific programs, IUSE, and CAREER programs. All of these and specific tracks for the IUSE program were listed as useful topics covered during the workshop with 66% of participants planning to submit a proposal to one of these other programs.

Only four comments were submitted by respondents. Three were positive and about the networking opportunities and event organization. The fourth communicated concern about their perceived lack of  information provided about the Noyce program during the workshop.

In conclusion, while the workshop didn’t completely meet all of its goals in terms of fostering joint-proposals, but it did start conversations between individuals who may collaborate in the future. The workshop also helped educate regional educators about related funding opportunities at NSF.
